38.text: (Gail Be) A great artist always knows

41.text: that the energy flows through them.

53.text: And the reason I'm a great artist,

54.text: I know how to move over and let the energy come through me.

112.text: beaded incessantly from the minute I started.

139.text: I began collecting beads 24 years ago.

143.text: I'd been diagnosed in 1989 with keratoconus

147.text: and while I was beading, my cornea ruptured.

150.text: And then the next one the next year also ruptured.

153.text: All of a sudden your sight's just gone,

155.text: and I was unable to bead for about 5 years.

158.text: I just really wanted to stay connected with beads.

162.text: And I collected beads, becoming a connoisseur

165.text: of the rarest beads, and then overnight, from 3 surgeries,

169.text: I saw 20/20, and then I had this awesome collection

173.text: and I started beading with that.

174.text: These are all vintage beads from Germany in the 1940s and '50s.

179.text: And what I do then is pour them out

182.text: and then I divide each of them into a color.

188.text: and that's because I'm pulling energy

191.text: back and forth for them to know I'm going to start using them

195.text: and me to get in my mind what colors I have,

198.text: 'cause once I start, I don't stop.

201.text: All my dresses that I come up with

203.text: I actually see them before I start.

205.text: It's a vision that comes in very quickly.

207.text: And since I don't sketch or draw or do mathematical calculations,

212.text: it's that one second of seeing the dress,

214.text: then I go through, and I see what beads I can match

217.text: and then pull them out of all the different compartments

220.text: and put them all together, and then I start working.

231.text: and there are even more people that sew.

234.text: And no one is doing fully-beaded dresses like me.

239.text: And to be an artist, you have to find a niche

242.text: of what nobody else is doing.

249.text: This is the Holy Grail of my whole business.

252.text: This is like the holy sanctuary, basically our temple or church

506.text: This is how we work-- we design all night,

509.text: into the wee hours of the night, then I go bead,

542.text: is that there are no interruptions.

545.text: The real beading for me is in private.

550.text: The reason I keep making my dresses and doing this is

554.text: to leave them for the world.

555.text: I think it's a complete waste when you have been given

560.text: gifted abilities to not use them,

562.text: and so I feel a responsibility to do that and out of all that,

567.text: fortunately, I really love to bead.

569.text: So every day that I'm beading, or every night,

572.text: I give thanks for allowing me to do something I love.

612.text: (Patrick K. Pryor) In every house I've lived in I've always made repairs

615.text: and fixed it up in some way, and so I've been

618.text: working on little projects every couple of months.

621.text: So it looks like there's several layers of wallpaper.

624.text: This is probably the original, closest to the plaster, then

626.text: there's some paint and then some other wallpaper on top of that.

630.text: This is kind of the analogous part to my painting

633.text: is that I'm actually laying down layers that I later uncover,

638.text: but exactly how they get uncovered is the unknown part.

643.text: It's interesting that becoming an artist was synonymous

645.text: with starting to learn how to work on an old house.

655.text: I was about 3 years old at my father's house.

658.text: He was a great drawer, my grandfather was a great artist,

662.text: and he would teach me how to draw.

666.text: When I first started painting, I was trying to make paintings

673.text: I was trying to make them larger and in color.

676.text: And then I found when I used many, many layers I could

680.text: add depth to the paintings and using transparent layers

683.text: and scraping and sanding, I can add even more layers

686.text: and combinations than I can with just using the brush.

689.text: I tried so many different things in painting.

692.text: I feel like my work changes almost every couple of years.

695.text: I have certain stylistic patterns that people recognize,

699.text: but I've been experimenting a lot.

721.text: Using layers allows transformation to happen

724.text: and allows me to work with something that's already there.

729.text: Oftentimes when I start a painting,

731.text: I have to create a painting that I'll then react to.

748.text: After I have that base layer on the painting,

751.text: then I'll start laying down these lines using tape.

755.text: The lines in the painter's tape was an important way

759.text: for me to have some stability in the composition,

764.text: some sort of a foundation, because frankly,

767.text: the idea of working on a blank canvas is daunting.

771.text: I try to start some paintings that way and I just can't do it,

775.text: so I have to have some sort of structure in place first,

782.text: This is always such a bittersweet process, it's like

785.text: kind of wrecking something I've been spending so much time on.

797.text: Then I start covering everything up with the white paint,

800.text: and I've tried lots of different colors, other tonal qualities.

807.text: the purity of the white paint

808.text: that's important for me to use as the next layer

813.text: And then that white layer allows me to scrape through

816.text: to then reveal the color and the lines beneath it.

820.text: [soft scraping ans sound of squirt bottle]

1313.text: (Billy) The reason why we called it The Colors of Gershwin,

1315.text: we wanted to put our colors to it.

1317.text: We tried to stay with all traditional melodies

1324.text: Once the arrangements were done, it came together really well.

1326.text: J.D. does an incredible job of putting a set list together

1330.text: and having a flow that makes a lot of sense,

1333.text: and that's part of his responsibility.

1335.text: And I disagreed with his flow, however, he was correct.

1339.text: And that's the thing that we realized is that

1341.text: in all of our positions within the family, is that

1344.text: we really do understand who is supposed to do what.

1347.text: 'Cause every one of the writers in the family

1349.text: or arrangers in the family have a different style of doing it.

1352.text: So J.D.'s way of doing it is not to make any notes.

1355.text: If you were to look at the lyrics on his sheet of paper,

1359.text: there's not one scratch, not one check, not a word written.

1362.text: Jevetta on the other hand, knows exactly, everything

1364.text: is written down, she's typed up all the background

1367.text: so she hears in her head and she goes this is what I'm hearing

1370.text: and this is what I want you to do.
